awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Fundamental Properties of Millimeter Wave Networks: Signal, Interference, and Connectivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Cellular communication networks have become one of society's most important and complex technologies. Mobile data usage has been approximately doubling every year since about 2008, which corresponds to a 1,000 times increase over a decade.  To meet this insatiable demand, much more bandwidth is required for cellular systems.  This requires going to (much) higher frequencies, since there is very little unused spectrum below about 10 GHz, especially at peak times in urban areas.  Significant amounts of lightly used spectrum is available in the "millimeter wave" (mmW) spectrum, defined here as being above 25 GHz.  There are numerous fundamental technical challenges in mobile data communication above 25 GHz, and the goal of this project is to explore these fundamental challenges and build new tools to overcome them.  The research undertaken should considerably impact the telecommunications industry and society as a whole, by enabling an entirely new paradigm for cellular communication networks.  In addition to theoretical contributions, the investigators will pursue an aggressive technology transition plan through their numerous government and industry partners. 

This project will develop new mathematical and analysis tools that uncover the potential of mmW cellular networks. The research agenda is built on the belief that the wealth of tools developed for lower frequency systems are insufficient to capture key mmW signal propagation features, specifically high directionality and blockage.  The research is structured as three inter-related thrusts, each with several proposed research tasks: mmW signal strength, mmW interference, and the mmW network connectivity. The research tasks are unified around several technical themes that cut across all three thrusts: (1) modeling mmW networks in 3D, including the obstacles for which statistical blocking models will be developed and validated with real building data; (2) accounting for signal and interference correlation in performance analysis, which will be significant in mmW due to their main randomizing factors being blocking and beam alignment rather than fading and shadowing; (3) accounting for and addressing the possibly severe effects of mobility on beam alignment and network connectivity. 

The developed theories will be used to devise useful models, parametrized by real building data to facilitate fast performance evaluation. Features of practical mmW transceivers like beam adaptation, mobility, and interference cancellation will be included and used to study key design tradeoffs. The new mathematical framework developed in this proposal will allow transparent and comprehensive performance analysis of mmW cellular systems, and enable the development and fair comparison of new communication techniques.

CIF: Medium: Fundamental Properties of Millimeter Wave Networks: Signal, Interference, and Connectivity

Cellular communication networks have become one of society's most important and complex technologies. This project on millimeter wave (mmWave) networks commenced in 2014, in the very early stages of 5G development and before any formal standardization activities began.  5G is heavily based on mmWave communication and in particular this is how 5G support data rates above 1 Gigabit per second: comparable to fiber optic connections   There were a great number of fundamental technical challenges to doing mobile data communication at these high frequencies, which is why it had never been accomplished. This project aimed to address some of these fundamental problems and produce theoretical guidance on how to solve and overcome them.

This project developed new theoretical techniques and tools that helped uncover the ultimate potential of mmWave cellular networks, and also provided guidance on how to design efficient and effective mmWave systems.

With regards to the first topic, we developed a comprehensive analysis framework for mmWave cellular systems based on stochastic geometry that has been widely built upon by other researchers.  For example, building on PI Heath's seminal analysis of mmWave cellular systems, we characterized the impact of correlated shadowing amongst different users, and showed the impact of macrodiversity (simultaneously connecting to multiple base stations) in view of random shadowing and blocking.  We developed novel techniques for analyzing multihop mmWave networks and the all-important initial access procedure whereby two mmWave transceivers align their beams to commence data transmissions.  We authored a technical yet accessible tutorial article based on this research that has been cited over 450 times and served as a guide to this topic. 

We also made several important practical discoveries during the course of the project.  As an example, we showed quantitatively that cellular operators could profitably share spectrum licenses in mmWave systems as opposed to having their own exclusive licenses.  We wrote the seminal theoretical paper on wirelessly self-backhauled mmWave networks, as well as several other follow on works, which are now a focus of ongoing and future 5G deployments of mmWave.  We studied decoupling the downlink and uplink of mmWave cellular networks, showing that it is preferable to not restrict mobile users to connecting to the same base station for both transmitting and receiving, which is also being done for the first time in 5G.  In short, our work has been timely and relevant to the cellular communication industry, as well as driving new research.

Modified by: Jeffrey G Andrews
